node_2: actress dressed as a polar bear
edge: Norm, pretending to be an actress dressed as a polar bear, auditions for Mr. Greene's commercial and is taken to dinner by Vera.
Mr. Greene has captured Norm's grandfather.
Mr. Greene confronts Norm with a tranquilizer gun because he suspects that Norm has come to free his grandfather.
Norm's popularity further increases Mr. Greene's approval ratings.
Mr. Greene uses recorded dialogue to claim that Norm supports his developments.
Vera's daughter Olympia tells Norm to speak out against Mr. Greene and his campaign so he can save the Arctic.
Norm supports his developments in the Arctic. Defeated, Norm is comforted by Vera and Olympia who reveal that Mr. Greene is developing more homes to install in the Arctic.
Mr. Greene is bribing a high-ranking member of the Polar Council,
After Vera resigns her position, she is hired by Pablo.
Norm and his grandfather get reunited after being freed by the lemmings.
Mr. Greene's reputation is ruined after his bribery is publicly revealed.
Because of his heroism, Norm is crowned the King of the Arctic,
The film Norm of the North had television commercials played on several channels during its release, according to [17].
The reviewer from The A.V. Club compares Norm of the North unfavorably to quality animated family films, such as those produced by Pixar.
The reviewer from The Observer labels Norm of the North as dull.
The context includes information that 21 out of 100 critics gave Norm of the North generally unfavorable reviews.
The reviewer from Mark Dujsik doesn't think Norm of the North cares about the animals of the Arctic.
The reviewer from Mark Dujsik doesn't think Norm of the North cares about the environment.
The reviewer from Mark Dujsik doesn't think Norm of the North cares about kids either.
According to a reviewer from The Observer, Norm of the North features a group of vulgar lemmings.
The reviewer from Variety predicts that Norm of the North will quickly head south to an ancillary afterlife.
In a post-Pixar world, where audiences have become accustomed to quality animated family films, Norm's existence as a low-budget animation is perceived as a waste of money.
Despite being hardly original ... 'Norm' has oodles of charm, a razor-sharp wit, and pacing that should keep even preschoolers attentive.
Your kids will enjoy Norm's companyâ€“he's funny and a role model for doing the right thing
The difference between Norm and other animated films is not just seen as condescending.
